Question: is space itself actually expanding as suggested in this video, or is the universe expanding because galaxies are moving apart THROUGH space? Because surely if the former is correct, then that means the size of a metre is increasing over time, which would make it impossible to detect because the value of c would also be increasing in order to appear constant? If space was itself expanding, so everything was gradually getting bigger, but light continued moving at the same speed, then we would observe a gradual decrease in the value of c over time. But conversely, if light was getting faster as space gets larger, then we would see no redshift. So surely the only workable solution is that space is not itself expanding, things are just moving apart through it?

The early statement "the galaxy, right now, is 32 billion light years away" is an entirely meaningless statement. Simultaneity doesn't work at a distance. This is relativity 101.

You can easily see things moving faster than c by looking at a star or even the moon and whipping your head around. Ah, but that's rotating, so it's cheating, I hear you cry. No, rotating frames of reference are perfectly fine in the General Theory of Relativity. That's why it's General. A corollary is that the artificial gravity such as in a rotating space station like in 2001 is just as real as the gravity on the Earth. In fact, locally, it's identical from the Equivalence Principle. At larger scales, it's just that the metric is different.

Relating all this stuff to Euclidean geometry and our common-sense notions of motion, position, and time, are fine if they help you understand something, but they usually make it more difficult. Brains just aren't configured to be able to understand large distances, speeds, times, and so forth and so on. They work pretty well locally, and Einsteinian relativity is a purely local theory (plus the assumption that it's still true everywhere and everywhen, which I think is adequately supported by Noether's Theorem.

Let "#" be matter (a raisin, a galaxy, whatever)
and let "_" represent the expansion (measured in space) per second. Each line is a second (T0, T1 ,T2 etc)

T0: #.#.#.#.#.#.#
T1: #._.#._.#._.#._.#._.#._.#

T3: #._._._.#._._._.#._._._.#._._._.#._._._.#._._._.#


The "." is only to be able to count individual units and does not intrinsically affect any measurement of the diagram.

So, at T0, all particles are touching, and there is no space between them.
In T1, the particles are separated.
Let's say for instance that the speed of expansion is 1/3rd that of the speed of light each second per space represented in "_" (Super fast, but not breaking the laws of physics.)
If you were to observe one unit to the next, everything is expanding REALLY Fast, but not necessarily faster than the speed of light.

in 1 second, or unit of time (from T0 to T1), it would appear as though another unit 6 units over is travelling almost double the speed of light.
No laws of physics are being broken here, it is just about perception, and how far away it is.

Game for a class.
Start a group of students in a close knit group near a visible point. Give them some balls that they can throw to each other. Ask them to walk away from each other in radials from the point where the group was centred. Mark the centre. Have them continue to throw balls to each other as they step away. Tell them to walk faster every few seconds as they throw and catch the balls. It won’t take long until they are too far to move and throw accurately as you tell them to move faster and keep passing the balls. They’ll reach their limits to throw and roll the balls to each other. It’s not a perfect model (nothing is) but it gives an intro to inflation and general relativity. You can discuss that the point students need to aim and throw to is beyond where their target starts.

Conversely you can reverse the game. Start students in parallel lines opposite each other on different sides of a sports field. Have them run to each other and throw balls from one side to another. Slow them down as they get closer to each other. Initially it may be too far to throw a ball directly. But eventually the ball will start to roll to the other side beyond the throwing distance. The catcher will walk up to a slow or stopped ball. Again not a perfect model but demonstrates interacting with something beyond the observable field. That shows the ball will move far steer than them as they slow down and the ball retains some momentum.

Eventually the person would transition to an even slower treadmill and appear to be moving towards us and of course also gaining ground on the treadmill. Ultimately, the person would be getting closer to us at an ever increasing speed because the treadmills that the person is running on are getting slower and slower. The fastest anyone could run on each individual treadmill is the universal speed limit. If the person ran away from us, then relative to us they’d appear to eventually be running faster than the speed of light, but on each individual treadmill they’d not be running faster than the speed of light.

The idea that there is a shared 'now' between events is essentially disproven by Special Relativity. So to say that a galaxy is "actually" further away than the image of it we observe, is a little incomplete to me.

That image, of that galaxy, (or event or whatever) is our causal link to that event. Sure we can predict, with good accuracy, what would happen if we got in a space ship and flew there (we may find the galaxy long dead), but for all intents, experiments, and purposes, the dead galaxy does not exist for observers who don't travel to it.

The 'observable universe' that is described here, sounds like two things. One is the actual light we observe from things in our present moment, and the other is this abstract idea of 'where all the things that emitted that light are right now'. I'm weirdly uncomfortable with the second part, such that that information is unobservable, casually disconnected, and relies on Aristotelian time.

What is confusing or counterintuitive about the expansion is the lack of explanation of what exactly is expanding. We were taught that space is overwhelming nothingness - an emptiness, a vacuum. How can nothing-ness expand? Or is it not nothingness after all? Vacuum is therefore not properly defined nor explained. To make matters worse, we ask what is space expanding into. We think of things taking up 'room'  in an exclusive way, so an expanding universe is taking up more and more room in what?

I'm thinking about light running on treadmills as a model for understanding this. Or escalators. Or those moving walkways at the airport. Imagine you are running AGAINST the direction of the moving walkway. At first, when you start your motion, the walkway will overpower your velocity and send you AWAY from your target. But if you keep accelerating, you will eventually overcome the velocity of the walkway. This is assuming a constant velocity walkway and a variable velocity you.

We need to sort of swap those. Now imagine a walkway that is expanding instead and that you've hit your stride and are running at a constant velocity on the walkway. There will be periods at the beginning where you move away from your target, but if you aren't too far, you'll eventually overcome that and start moving toward your target.

An animation of people running on magical expanding airport walkways might be helpful for us.

I'm also wondering what Einstein would have done with this whole expanding spacetime thing if he had embraced it earlier, since it seems like a 3rd theory of relativity should pop out of this. After all, it must be pretty hard to tell how you are moving when you're on a silly expanding walkway since everything you see around you is warped by the experience.

1) An object cannot exceed the speed of light however, 2 objects moving in opposite directions at just over half the speed of light would appear to exceed that limit.

3) Knowing this, the time it takes light to travel from 1 point in space to another would actually be further then the distance light could travel in a set amount of years. We are therefore looking into the past at objects that are no longer where they appear.

B)The object we are observing estimated distance and trajectory.
C)The speed at which space is expanding multiplied by the distance apart as the further away 2 objects appear the greater the % of expansion will continually shift the actual distance a part.

The problematic part in "how distant that galaxy is from us?" is actually "is", with its implicit "now", i.e. "at this instant", for the simple fact that in GR what constitutes the "this instant", not just here where I am (and, for You, where You are) but rather extended over space-like distances, is not objectively defined, and this lack of definition is not relevant mechanically because the framework of causation, the "weave" of causal relations, is not reliant on such a notion of "this instant".
Our naïve notion of this instant, intended as pre-relativistic, conflate the events which are space-like separated from us into a space-only volume with null time-like extension. The latter is a characteristic we are used to ascribe to an instant. In truth, we intuitively project our physical experience, which occurs locally "here" in both space and time, to its remote causations placed in the space-only extension, which constitutes the pre-relativistic "instant". This, obviously, relies on an infinite speed of light, and fails in SR and then in GR.
Indeed, with SR, the "instant", extended beyond "here", spans the time dimension, and it is actually, for each event, the 4D volume of space-like separated events from the reference event.
While there are ways to set a definition of "now" (so that, in every event of its extension, it doesn't have a time-like extension) in GR, they are not relevant for causal relations, i.e. mechanically, and they do not represent our subjective physical perspectives, since these are about what happened in our past cones, not on spatially-separated events from us (remember how this works in our pre-relativistic intuition). In other words, these ways are conventional, but not fundamentally objective for the theory (which doesn't mean they don't have a well defined significance).
As soon as the "instant" "over there" spans the time dimension, talking about what that thing "over there" "is" is somewhat misleading if it forgets to point out that it is, in fact, not about a state at a fixed time, but actually a whole evolution of the state respect to time (which "now" does not affect me and which "now" I do not affect).
In the sense of the "now" as the volume of space-like separated events from us, that galaxy that we see at 13bly from us (i.e., that we see at the local now because the light from it traveled for 13by), "is" actually at 13bly, as well as at 30bly, and as well as at infinite distance from us (if it is already so far that the light from us emitted now will not reach it due to the universe expansion).

I was really confused at first but I think I got it. Correct me if I’m missing something.

The idea that light can travel away from us, stop, and then come toward us is only the case when viewed from our perspective (on earth). The light in question is always traveling in our direction relative to the local patch of space (the space it’s currently moving through) but since space itself is moving away from us, it would appear as if that light were traveling away from us if the space around it is receding faster than the speed of light.

It’s sort of like those people mover conveyor belts at the airport. Imagine earth is at one end of the conveyor belt and the surface of the belt is moving away from earth. If you tried to walk toward earth (opposite the direction of the belt), you would have to walk faster than the belt to make it back to earth. If you walked at the speed of the belt, you would stay put, and if you walked slower than the belt, the belt would win and you would move away from earth.

Now imagine the speed of the belt is greater the farther you are from earth. As you walk at a constant speed (speed of light) with the belt initially moving faster than you, you would initially be moving away from earth. Then as you moved along the belt (through space), the belt speed would decrease enough until the belt is going at the same speed as you. Now you would appear stationary relative to earth. Then as you continue, the belt speed would keep decreasing so that now you are going faster than the belt. You would now be moving toward earth, appearing to speed up until you reached the earth (at the speed of light).

This may not be a perfect analogy but it makes sense to me. I’d never thought about it before but it’s certainly a mind-bending concept.
